speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: SCENE III. London. The palace.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Enter the KING, NORTHUMBERLAND, WORCESTER, HOTSPUR, SIR WALTER BLUNT, with others

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: My blood hath been too cold and temperate,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Unapt to stir at these indignities,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And you have found me; for accordingly

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: You tread upon my patience: but be sure

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I will from henceforth rather be myself,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Mighty and to be fear'd, than my condition;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which hath been smooth as oil, soft as young down,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And therefore lost that title of respect

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which the proud soul ne'er pays but to the proud.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Our house, my sovereign liege, little deserves

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The scourge of greatness to be used on it;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And that same greatness too which our own hands

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Have holp to make so portly.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord.--

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Worcester, get thee gone; for I do see

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Danger and disobedience in thine eye:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: O, sir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And majesty might never yet endure

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The moody frontier of a servant brow.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: You have good leave to leave us: when we need

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Your use and counsel, we shall send for you.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exit Worcester

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: You were about to speak.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To North

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yea, my good lord.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Those prisoners in your highness' name demanded,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Were, as he says, not with such strength denied

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: As is deliver'd to your majesty:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Either envy, therefore, or misprison

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Is guilty of this fault and not my son.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My liege, I did deny no prisoners.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But I remember, when the fight was done,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When I was dry with rage and extreme toil,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Came there a certain lord, neat, and trimly dress'd,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Fresh as a bridegroom; and his chin new reap'd

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Show'd like a stubble-land at harvest-home;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He was perfumed like a milliner;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And 'twixt his finger and his thumb he held

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A pouncet-box, which ever and anon

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He gave his nose and took't away again;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Who therewith angry, when it next came there,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Took it in snuff; and still he smiled and talk'd,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He call'd them untaught knaves, unmannerly,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To bring a slovenly unhandsome corse

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Betwixt the wind and his nobility.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: With many holiday and lady terms

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He question'd me; amongst the rest, demanded

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My prisoners in your majesty's behalf.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I then, all smarting with my wounds being cold,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To be so pester'd with a popinjay,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Out of my grief and my impatience,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Answer'd neglectingly I know not what,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He should or he should not; for he made me mad

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To see him shine so brisk and smell so sweet

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And talk so like a waiting-gentlewoman

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of guns and drums and wounds,--God save the mark!--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And telling me the sovereign'st thing on earth

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Was parmaceti for an inward bruise;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And that it was great pity, so it was,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This villanous salt-petre should be digg'd

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Out of the bowels of the harmless earth,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Which many a good tall fellow had destroy'd

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: So cowardly; and but for these vile guns,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He would himself have been a soldier.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This bald unjointed chat of his, my lord,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I answer'd indirectly, as I said;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And I beseech you, let not his report

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Come current for an accusation

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Betwixt my love and your high majesty.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: The circumstance consider'd, good my lord,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Whate'er Lord Harry Percy then had said

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: To such a person and in such a place,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: At such a time, with all the rest retold,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: May reasonably die and never rise

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: To do him wrong or any way impeach

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: What then he said, so he unsay it now.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Why, yet he doth deny his prisoners,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But with proviso and exception,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: That we at our own charge shall ransom straight

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: His brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Who, on my soul, hath wilfully betray'd

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The lives of those that he did lead to fight

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Against that great magician, damn'd Glendower,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Whose daughter, as we hear, the Earl of March

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Hath lately married. Shall our coffers, then,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Be emptied to redeem a traitor home?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Shall we but treason? and indent with fears,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: When they have lost and forfeited themselves?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: No, on the barren mountains let him starve;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: For I shall never hold that man my friend

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To ransom home revolted Mortimer.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Revolted Mortimer!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He never did fall off, my sovereign liege,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But by the chance of war; to prove that true

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Needs no more but one tongue for all those wounds,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Those mouthed wounds, which valiantly he took

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When on the gentle Severn's sedgy bank,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In single opposition, hand to hand,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He did confound the best part of an hour

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In changing hardiment with great Glendower:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Three times they breathed and three times did

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: they drink,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Upon agreement, of swift Severn's flood;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Who then, affrighted with their bloody looks,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Ran fearfully among the trembling reeds,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And hid his crisp head in the hollow bank,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Bloodstained with these valiant combatants.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Never did base and rotten policy

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Colour her working with such deadly wounds;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nor could the noble Mortimer

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Receive so many, and all willingly:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Then let not him be slander'd with revolt.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Thou dost belie him, Percy, thou dost belie him;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: He never did encounter with Glendower:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I tell thee,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: He durst as well have met the devil alone

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: As Owen Glendower for an enemy.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Art thou not ashamed? But, sirrah, henceforth

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Send me your prisoners with the speediest means,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Or you shall hear in such a kind from me

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: As will displease you. My Lord Northumberland,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: We licence your departure with your son.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exeunt King Henry, Blunt, and train

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: An if the devil come and roar for them,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I will not send them: I will after straight

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And tell him so; for I will ease my heart,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Albeit I make a hazard of my head.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: What, drunk with choler? stay and pause awhile:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Here comes your uncle.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Re-enter WORCESTER

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Speak of Mortimer!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: 'Zounds, I will speak of him; and let my soul

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Want mercy, if I do not join with him:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Yea, on his part I'll empty all these veins,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And shed my dear blood drop by drop in the dust,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But I will lift the down-trod Mortimer

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: As high in the air as this unthankful king,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: As this ingrate and canker'd Bolingbroke.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Brother, the king hath made your nephew mad.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Who struck this heat up after I was gone?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He will, forsooth, have all my prisoners;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And when I urged the ransom once again

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of my wife's brother, then his cheek look'd pale,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And on my face he turn'd an eye of death,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I cannot blame him: was not he proclaim'd

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: By Richard that dead is the next of blood?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: He was; I heard the proclamation:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And then it was when the unhappy king,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: --Whose wrongs in us God pardon!--did set forth

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Upon his Irish expedition;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: From whence he intercepted did return

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To be deposed and shortly murdered.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And for whose death we in the world's wide mouth

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Live scandalized and foully spoken of.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But soft, I pray you; did King Richard then

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Heir to the crown?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: He did; myself did hear it.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nay, then I cannot blame his cousin king,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That wished him on the barren mountains starve.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But shall it be that you, that set the crown

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Upon the head of this forgetful man

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And for his sake wear the detested blot

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of murderous subornation, shall it be,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That you a world of curses undergo,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Being the agents, or base second means,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The cords, the ladder, or the hangman rather?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O, pardon me that I descend so low,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To show the line and the predicament

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Wherein you range under this subtle king;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Shall it for shame be spoken in these days,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Or fill up chronicles in time to come,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That men of your nobility and power

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Did gage them both in an unjust behalf,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: As both of you--God pardon it!--have done,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To put down Richard, that sweet lovely rose,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: An plant this thorn, this canker, Bolingbroke?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And shall it in more shame be further spoken,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That you are fool'd, discarded and shook off

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: By him for whom these shames ye underwent?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: No; yet time serves wherein you may redeem

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Your banish'd honours and restore yourselves

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Into the good thoughts of the world again,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Revenge the jeering and disdain'd contempt

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of this proud king, who studies day and night

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To answer all the debt he owes to you

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Even with the bloody payment of your deaths:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Therefore, I say--

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Peace, cousin, say no more:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And now I will unclasp a secret book,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And to your quick-conceiving discontents

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I'll read you matter deep and dangerous,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As full of peril and adventurous spirit

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As to o'er-walk a current roaring loud

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If he fall in, good night! or sink or swim:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Send danger from the east unto the west,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: So honour cross it from the north to south,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And let them grapple: O, the blood more stirs

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To rouse a lion than to start a hare!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Imagination of some great exploit

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To pluck bright honour from the pale-faced moon,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Or dive into the bottom of the deep,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Where fathom-line could never touch the ground,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And pluck up drowned honour by the locks;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: So he that doth redeem her thence might wear

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Without corrival, all her dignities:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But out upon this half-faced fellowship!

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: He apprehends a world of figures here,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: But not the form of what he should attend.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Good cousin, give me audience for a while.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I cry you mercy.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Those same noble Scots

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: That are your prisoners,--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I'll keep them all;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: By God, he shall not have a Scot of them;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shall not:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I'll keep them, by this hand.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: You start away

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And lend no ear unto my purposes.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Those prisoners you shall keep.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nay, I will; that's flat:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He said he would not ransom Mortimer;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Forbad my tongue to speak of Mortimer;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But I will find him when he lies asleep,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And in his ear I'll holla 'Mortimer!'

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nay,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I'll have a starling shall be taught to speak

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nothing but 'Mortimer,' and give it him

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To keep his anger still in motion.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Hear you, cousin; a word.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: All studies here I solemnly defy,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Save how to gall and pinch this Bolingbroke:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But that I think his father loves him not

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And would be glad he met with some mischance,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I would have him poison'd with a pot of ale.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Farewell, kinsman: I'll talk to you

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: When you are better temper'd to attend.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Why, what a wasp-stung and impatient fool

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Art thou to break into this woman's mood,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Why, look you, I am whipp'd and scourged with rods,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nettled and stung with pismires, when I hear

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of this vile politician, Bolingbroke.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In Richard's time,--what do you call the place?--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A plague upon it, it is in Gloucestershire;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: 'Twas where the madcap duke his uncle kept,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: His uncle York; where I first bow'd my knee

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Unto this king of smiles, this Bolingbroke,--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: 'Sblood!--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When you and he came back from Ravenspurgh.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: At Berkley castle.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: You say true:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Why, what a candy deal of courtesy

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This fawning greyhound then did proffer me!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Look,'when his infant fortune came to age,'

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And 'gentle Harry Percy,' and 'kind cousin;'

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O, the devil take such cozeners! God forgive me!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Good uncle, tell your tale; I have done.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Nay, if you have not, to it again;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: We will stay your leisure.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I have done, i' faith.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Then once more to your Scottish prisoners.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Deliver them up without their ransom straight,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And make the Douglas' son your only mean

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For powers in Scotland; which, for divers reasons

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Which I shall send you written, be assured,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Will easily be granted. You, my lord,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To Northumberland

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Your son in Scotland being thus employ'd,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Shall secretly into the bosom creep

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Of that same noble prelate, well beloved,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The archbishop.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of York, is it not?

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: True; who bears hard

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: His brother's death at Bristol, the Lord Scroop.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I speak not this in estimation,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As what I think might be, but what I know

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Is ruminated, plotted and set down,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And only stays but to behold the face

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Of that occasion that shall bring it on.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I smell it: upon my life, it will do well.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Before the game is afoot, thou still let'st slip.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Why, it cannot choose but be a noble plot;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And then the power of Scotland and of York,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To join with Mortimer, ha?

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And so they shall.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In faith, it is exceedingly well aim'd.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And 'tis no little reason bids us speed,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To save our heads by raising of a head;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For, bear ourselves as even as we can,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The king will always think him in our debt,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And think we think ourselves unsatisfied,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Till he hath found a time to pay us home:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And see already how he doth begin

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To make us strangers to his looks of love.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He does, he does: we'll be revenged on him.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Cousin, farewell: no further go in this

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Than I by letters shall direct your course.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: When time is ripe, which will be suddenly,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I'll steal to Glendower and Lord Mortimer;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Where you and Douglas and our powers at once,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As I will fashion it, shall happily meet,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Which now we hold at much uncertainty.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Farewell, good brother: we shall thrive, I trust.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Uncle, Adieu: O, let the hours be short

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Till fields and blows and groans applaud our sport!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Exeunt
